articles.headline: A Charity Accepts Uber Stock as Donations. Then Uses It to Pay Staff Bonuses. Is That O.K.?
articles.snippet: Entrepreneurs who own stakes in private companies can donate some of their equity to Charity: water. The proceeds will eventually be paid out to the nonprofit’s employees.
articles.abstract: Entrepreneurs who own stakes in private companies can donate some of their equity to Charity: water. The proceeds will eventually be paid out to the nonprofit’s employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, the founder of a charity that is focused on making sure everyone on earth has clean water and a co-founder of an e-commerce mattress company met for lunch at a SoHo restaurant. As the two ate, the talk inevitably turned to start-ups.

articles.headline: One Man vs. McKinsey: A Billionaire Says the Consultancy Has Rigged the Bankruptcy System
articles.snippet: Jay Alix is waging a court battle against the powerful advisory firm. McKinsey says he’s just a disgruntled competitor.
articles.abstract: Jay Alix is waging a court battle against the powerful advisory firm. McKinsey says he’s just a disgruntled competitor.
articles.lead_paragraph: You can’t have divided loyalties when guiding a company through bankruptcy. If you’re helping it cut debt, you can’t be its lender. If you’re auctioning off its assets, you can’t put in a bid.

articles.headline: To Halt Energy Slide, Mexico Turns to a Trusted Provider: Mexico
articles.snippet: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador wants to limit private and foreign investment while strengthening state-owned giants that analysts say are inefficient and corrupt.
articles.abstract: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador wants to limit private and foreign investment while strengthening state-owned giants that analysts say are inefficient and corrupt.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULA, Mexico — President Andrés Manuel López Obrador envisions a future in which Mexico produces more oil, gasoline and electricity. But his strategy to get there relies on reaching back into his country’s past.

articles.headline: Uber, Losing $1.8 Billion a Year, Reveals I.P.O. Filing
articles.snippet: The world’s largest ride-hailing service unveiled its prospectus for what is likely to be the biggest initial public offering for years.
articles.abstract: The world’s largest ride-hailing service unveiled its prospectus for what is likely to be the biggest initial public offering for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber, the ride-hailing service that has upended transportation around the world, took a major step toward the largest initial public offering in years when it officially unveiled its finances in a prospectus on Thursday.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Kate Conger

articles.headline: A Charred Gas Can, a Receipt and an Arrest in Fires of 3 Black Churches
articles.snippet: The 21-year-old son of a sheriff’s deputy was charged in connection with the blazes that destroyed three black churches in Louisiana.
articles.abstract: The 21-year-old son of a sheriff’s deputy was charged in connection with the blazes that destroyed three black churches in Louisiana.
articles.lead_paragraph: OPELOUSAS, La. — While the victims prayed for the soul of the arsonist who burned down their houses of worship, investigators rushed to assemble clues, worried the assailant would strike again.
articles.byline: By Alan Blinder, Richard Fausset and John Eligon

articles.headline: Assange: A Self-Proclaimed Foe of Secrecy Who Inspires Both Admiration and Fury
articles.snippet: From his beginnings as a teenage hacker in Australia to his arrest this week in London, the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been a deeply divisive figure.
articles.abstract: From his beginnings as a teenage hacker in Australia to his arrest this week in London, the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has been a deeply divisive figure.
articles.lead_paragraph: The shaky video clips of Julian Assange’s arrest flashed around the world on Thursday, the white-bearded prophet of the age of leaks being hauled by unsmiling security officers to a gray van marked Police.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: China Yields on Malaysia Rail Project as Global Infrastructure Program Is Re-Examined
articles.snippet: The government said work on the East Coast Rail Link would resume after its price tag, originally projected at up to $20 billion, was cut nearly in half.
articles.abstract: The government said work on the East Coast Rail Link would resume after its price tag, originally projected at up to $20 billion, was cut nearly in half.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When a cross-country rail line was unveiled in 2017, the Malaysian prime minister hailed it as a “game changer,” a major transportation upgrade that would be built and financed by Chinese money and Chinese companies. It was a showcase project for China’s effort to expand its geopolitical influence around the world through a vast infrastructure program.

articles.headline: He Has Driven for Uber Since 2012. He Makes About $40,000 a Year.
articles.snippet: Peter Ashlock has completed 25,000 trips for Uber. As insiders cash in with what may be a $100 billion public offering, he’s on the road to nowhere.
articles.abstract: Peter Ashlock has completed 25,000 trips for Uber. As insiders cash in with what may be a $100 billion public offering, he’s on the road to nowhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: COTATI, Calif. — Uber’s public stock offering next month will make a bunch of people remarkably rich. Peter Ashlock is not one of them, although he has toiled for the ride-hailing company almost since the beginning.

articles.headline: Costs for Boeing Start to Pile Up as 737 Max Remains Grounded
articles.snippet: As the situation drags on, the aerospace giant and the airlines that rely on its planes have been scrambling to adjust, and the costs are growing.
articles.abstract: As the situation drags on, the aerospace giant and the airlines that rely on its planes have been scrambling to adjust, and the costs are growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the 22 months that Boeing’s 737 Max flew commercially before it was grounded, the jet became the company’s flagship as well as an integral part of the global aviation system, and the American economy.

articles.headline: Over 3 A.M. Dissent, Supreme Court Says Alabama Execution May Proceed
articles.snippet: The 5-to-4 ruling, issued in the middle of the night, provided a rare glimpse of the inner workings of a court bitterly divided on the death penalty.
articles.abstract: The 5-to-4 ruling, issued in the middle of the night, provided a rare glimpse of the inner workings of a court bitterly divided on the death penalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The dissent, tinged with anguish and filled with bitter accusations, was not ready until almost 3 a.m. It described a rupture in the carefully tended norms of civility at the Supreme Court. And it provided a rare glimpse into ordinarily secret deliberations.

articles.headline: U.S. Retail Stores’ Planned Closings Already Exceed 2018 Total
articles.snippet: Less than halfway through April, companies have announced plans to close 5,994 stores, above the 5,854 that shut last year.
articles.abstract: Less than halfway through April, companies have announced plans to close 5,994 stores, above the 5,854 that shut last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: As an executive vice president at Great American Group, a firm that helps liquidate the merchandise, clothing racks and mannequins at stores that are closing, Ryan Mulcunry has been watching booms and busts in the retail industry for almost two decades.
